definitions: provide support for someone or something

examples.text: go up there and tell them—I'll back you up
more than 100 uniformed officers and detectives are working on the case, backed up by specialists from the National Crime Agency
U.S. troops were backed up by forces from European countries

notes.text: "back someone or something up", "back up someone or something"

definitions: confirm or corroborate a statement or theory

examples.text: Pedro's story is backed up by the accounts of three other young people who worked on the campaign
she has the data to back up her claim

definitions: make a spare copy of data or a disk.
shortDefinitions: make spare copy of data or disk

definitions: (of vehicles) form a line due to congestion

examples.text: the traffic began to back up

shortDefinitions: form into queue due to congestion

definitions: cause vehicles to form a line due to congestion

examples.text: the traffic was backed up a mile in each direction
all lanes were closed, backing up traffic for miles on the key north–south artery

shortDefinitions: cause vehicles to form into queue due to congestion

definitions: be experiencing a backlog of work or other things that need to be dealt with

examples.text: your car won't be ready today as we're really backed up
she backed up until she found herself against the wall
one of us backed up so the other could pass

definitions: explain the background of a situation or return to an earlier point in an account

examples.text: I know it's a complicated story, so let me back up a little

definitions: (of running water) accumulate behind an obstruction.
